Red-headed Woodpecker: distinct border where the red head meets the white chest
black wings with large white patches
pointed beak, often used for pecking at wood
zygodactyl feet (two toes facing forward, two facing backward)
Downy Woodpecker: Small size, about 6-7 inches in length
Males have a small red patch on the back of the head (nape)
Often seen on tree trunks or branches
Bewick Wren: brownish-grey upper parts and white underparts
relatively long tail often held upright
subtle streaks on its back and sides
Cactus Wren: long tail with white tips on the outer feathers
Carolina Wren: short tail that is often cocked upwards
faint barring on wings and tail
relatively long legs for a small bird
House Wren: faint, darker barring on wings and tail
upright tail, often seen cocked above the back
pale eyebrow stripe (not always very prominent)
relatively plain face with subtle streaking
Marsh Wren: brownish upperparts with a lighter, buffy underbelly
dark cap or crown on the head
often seen among reeds or marsh vegetation
usually has an upright tail position
Rock Wren: streaked with white and dark brown
usually seen in rocky or arid terrain
Winter Wren: brown coloration with darker barring on wings and tail
short, upright tail often held at an angle
fine, dark barring on flanks and belly
relatively large feet and legs for its size
active and often found in dense underbrush or near fallen logs
Common Yellowthroat: distinct black mask across the face (males only)
white or grayish border around the black mask
